DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua Expels 20 U.S. Diplomats In Retaliation For Panama Incident
Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to CORRECT Nicaragua expelling 20 diplomats and ordering the mission to cut its support staff to 100 people. Pickup 2nd graf pvs, `The announcement...'
DOC.TEXT: President Daniel Ortega said Friday that 20 American diplomats will be expelled in retaliation for an incident at the Nicaraguan Embassy in Panama. Ortega also ordered the embassy to cut its service and administrative staff from 320 people to 100 people. It was not immediately known how many are American. The 20 diplomats will be given 72 hours to leave Nicaragua after their names are made public, Ortega said in the announcement broadcast nationwide by a government radio network. The announcement came just hours after Nicaragua's amabassador to Panaman, Antenor Ferrey, said U.S. troops surrounded his residence in Panama City, ordered all personnel inside to evacuate and searched the building for weapons. Ortega called the diplomatic incident ``unheard of.'' The troops seized five rifles inside the residence that Ferrey said were there for self-defense. A U.S. Army colonel in charge of the operation later apologized and returned the rifles, Ferrey said. ``They acted arrogantly, like Rambos!'' Ortega said of the incident. ``We were at grave risk a political-military clash with the United States, which has maintained an aggressive attitude against Latin American countries.'' Ortega claimed the U.S. soldiers ``stole more than $2,000 and took away some clothes from the residence.'' U.S. Embassy and military officials said they had no information on the incident. Ortega's announcement also said the U.S. Embassy will be forced to ``compact its 220 of its personnel of 320, leaving only 100 in service.'' This was taken to mean that another 220 embassy employees, mostly Nicaraguan administrative and service personnel, will also be forced to leave their jobs. It was not immediately clear if the embassy had that many support personnel. The phones of the embassy and the homes of several senior officers were either not answered or rang busy. U.S. diplomatic representation in Nicaragua was lowered when Ortega's leftist Sandinista regime expelled Ambassador Richard Melton and eight other American diplomats in July 1988, accusing them of meddling in Nicaragua's affairs. The government accused the diplomats of inciting street demonstrations against the Sandinista regime. The U.S. denied the accusation. Since then, the embassy has been headed by charge d'affairs John Leonard, and relations have not been too cordial. Diplomatic tension between the countries has been increasing since U.S. troops invaded Panama on Dec. 20 and deposed strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega. American troops have been surrounding the Nicaraguan Embassy offices in Panama City along with those of the Cuban and Libyan embassies.
